q1: What types of color blindness are simulated?
a1: We simulate protanopia (red-blind), deuteranopia (green-blind), tritanopia (blue-yellow blind), and achromatopsia (total color blindness/monochromacy).
a2: The simulation uses standard color vision deficiency transformation matrices widely used in accessibility research. Results closely approximate the actual perception.
q3: Why is this tool important for designers?
a3: About 8% of men have some form of color blindness. Testing your color choices ensures your designs are accessible and usable by all users.
q4: How many colors can I test?
a4: You can test between 2 and 10 colors simultaneously, making it easy to check your entire design palette.
a5: Yes, the Color Blindness Simulator is completely free with no usage limits.
